additionalTextInformation.text:
"When I compare the faces in this painting with other works by Cranach I cannot imagine that this painting was produced in the Cranach workshop. The hair which was frequently highlighted with white paint appears atypical. Also the faces of the people do not fit in the Cranach-scheme. This should serve for further discussion."
[Transl. comment by cda user Dirk Eilers, Kronach, 19 Jan. 2012]

The panel was presumably formally part of a wing panel and has been separated from its other half (image either above or below); furthermore the original reverse of  panel is no longer present and it has been reinforced with two battens.  
[Herrschaft, cda 2014]

pageContext.description:
Christ bends down in front of a gate and writes in the earth with his right hand. The adulteress stands beside him, in front and behind him there are mercenary soldiers and Pharisees. A dog scratches himself in the foreground. 

[Miklós Gálos, Szépmuvészeti Múzeum, Budapest 2011]
pageContext.dimensions:
Dimensions of support: 68.7 x 46.2 x 0.4 cm
[cda 2014]
pageContext.markings:
none, as the panel has been thinned (with a plane) and cradled, only the label with the [current] inventory number (Országos Képtár, Szépmuvészeti Múzeum)

[Szépmuvészeti Múzeum, revised 2011]

metadata.title: Woman Taken in Adultery

pageContext.provenance:
- in the collection of the Archduke Leopold Wilhelm, Brussels. In the viennese inventory of the collection from 1659: 'Nr. 800. Ein Stückhel von Öhlfarb auf Holcz, warin vnnser Herr Gott mitt den Pharisehen, so die Ehebrecherin zu ihme pringen. In einer glatt vergulden Rahmen, das innere Leistel schwartz, hoch 3 Spann 8 ¿ Finger vnndt 2 Spann 7 Finger braith. Original von Lucas Cranich.' (No. 800. A work in oil on wood, depicting Christ with the Pharisees when the adultress approaches him. In a smooth gilded frame with a black inner moulding, height 3 Spann 8 ¿ Finger and 2 Spann 7 Finger wide. Original by Lucas Cranich.) 
(the measurements convert as: 80.08 × 56.16 cm; the paintings were measured in their frames.)

- engraving in: Prodromus oder Vor Licht des eröffneten Schau- und Wunder Prachtes aller deren an dem kaisl. Hof, sich befindlichen Kunst Schätzen und Kostbarkeiten, von J. Stampart und A. J. Prenner, Wien, 1735 Tf. 21 top left(inverted): 1770 - Schloß Pressburg (Bratislava)

- 1848 the court chamber commitee of Ofen (Buda, Budapest) transferred the painting to the Hungarian National Museum in Pest (Budapest) Inv. No. Átalános Képtár (Paintings Gallery): 276

-1877 Országos Képtár (National Gallery), Budapest (Acquisition No.: 151. Here kept in storage)

- 1906 Szépmuvészeti Múzeum, Budapest (storage)

[Szépmuvészeti Múzeum, revised 2011]
pageContext.relatedWorks:
- Lucas Cranach the Elder, 'Woman taken in Adultery', drawing, 1509, Herzog Anton Ulrich-Museum, Braunschweig, Inv. No. Z 28

- Circle of Lucas Cranach the Elder, 'Woman taken in Adultery', lime wood, 113.5 × 92 cm, Wallraf-Richartz-Museum, Cologne, WRM 530 

[Szépmuvészeti Múzeum, Budapest 2011]

restorationSurveys.overallAnalysis:
- washboard-like warping of the support resulting from the cradle 
- Craquelée extends over the entire painted surface, primarily in the direction of the grain
- retouches 
- open joins and splits in the support, partial flaking along the splits 
- yellowed varnish

tests.text:
- the support is made of coniferous wood with the grain running horizontally 
- 5 planks, dimensions (verso): 7.6 (l.); 7.4; 10.8; 13.4; 7.0 (r.) cm
- trimmed along the top edge 
- the cradle is made of coniferous wood 
- beneath the cradle - along the upper and lower edges - depression in the wood containing a grey substance; probably from a wooden batten used to reinforce the panel
- a thin, white ground extends to the edge of the panel

- the painted surface extends to the edge of the panel 
- along the left and right edges thin black painted lines (2-3 mm in width) were applied on the painted surface

DESCRIPTION

Tools/Materials:
- fluid, black medium and brushes of varying widths 
 
Type/Ductus:
- detailed and freehand underdrawing 
- thin to broader lines 
 
Function:
- relatively binding for the final painted version; lines delineate contours and describe the essential details and the facial features; no representation of volume 

Deviations:
- alterations made during the painting process to clearly define form 

INTERPRETATION

Attribution:
- workshop of Lucas Cranach the Elder


[Smith, Sandner, Heydenreich, cda 2014]
